perturbation.original_text:
15. Payment of Money. In consideration of the services to be rendered under this Agreement as set forth above, the Company shall be
entitled to compensation in the amount of $150,000.00 (One Hundred Fifty Thousand Dollars), to be paid in equal installments of $37,500.00
(Thirty Seven Thousand Five Hundred Dollars) on January 1, 2008, April 1, 2008, July 1, 2008 and October 1, 2008. If Cano fails to make any
payment when required by this Agreement, the Company shall have the option of canceling this Agreement following the passage of ten
(10) days after having given Cano written notice of its default. While the Company shall have no further obligation to Cano following
cancellation of the Agreement, Cano shall remain liable for all unpaid installments for the then current term of the Agreement, which
installments shall be immediately due and payable.
perturbation.changed_text:
15. Payment of Money. In consideration of the services to be rendered under this Agreement as set forth above, the Company shall be
entitled to compensation in the amount of $150,000.00 (One Hundred Fifty Thousand Dollars). If Cano fails to make any
payment when required by this Agreement, the Company shall have the option of canceling this Agreement following the passage of ten
(10) days after having given Cano written notice of its default. While the Company shall have no further obligation to Cano following
cancellation of the Agreement, Cano's payment obligations will be reassessed based on the shows delivered up until the point of cancellation.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly defined the payment schedule and consequences of default. The revised text removes the certainty of the payment schedule by omitting the installment dates. Furthermore, it introduces ambiguity by stating that upon cancellation, Cano's payment obligations will be "reassessed", contradicting the original clause that all unpaid installments for the current term become immediately due and payable, thus weakening the company's legal standing to claim the full remaining amount.

perturbation.original_text: 18. Assignment. This Agreement may not be assigned by either party without the prior written consent of the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: 18. Assignment. This Agreement may be assigned by either party. The assigning party must notify the other party within 30 days of the assignment.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause strictly prohibited assignment without prior written consent. The revised clause directly contradicts this by stating that either party may assign the agreement, only requiring notification within 30 days. This creates a clear conflict regarding the assignability of the contract and the requirements for doing so.

perturbation.original_text:
19. Other Agreements. This Agreement supersedes any and all other agreements, either oral or in writing, between the parties with respect
to the subject matter of this contract, and contains all of the covenants and agreements between the parties with respect to the subject
matter. Each party to this contract acknowledges that no representations, inducements, promises, or agreements, orally or otherwise, have
been made by any party, or anyone acting on behalf of any party, that are not set forth in this contract, and that no agreement, statement, or promise not contained in this contract shall be valid or binding.
perturbation.changed_text:
19. Other Agreements. This Agreement supersedes any and all other agreements, either oral or in writing, between the parties with respect
to the subject matter of this contract, and contains all of the covenants and agreements between the parties with respect to the subject
matter. However, any prior oral agreements made before November 1, 2007, regarding the Honey Hole show's creative direction shall remain valid.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause is an integration clause meant to prevent outside agreements from influencing the contract's interpretation. The revised text introduces a significant exception, stating that prior oral agreements regarding the show's creative direction remain valid. This directly contradicts the superseding nature of the contract and creates uncertainty about which agreements govern the creative aspects of the show. It also opens the door for disputes based on potentially unverifiable oral promises.
